If you go to a French restaurant, you don't expect to see burgers.
If you want to market your restaurant as a seafood restaurant, stick to seafood!
If you end up selling more chicken than seafood it's because somehow your image, your marketing and your menu is off.
You need to build the reputation of a seafood restaurant in order to attract seafood consumers.
You can only do that if you primarily sell seafood.
It's okay to have one or two alternatives for groups and families.
I think you are right to minimize the chicken.
After all if your goal is to sell meals by pleasing as many people as possible, just open a McDonalds!

Blame the freedom of expression of the internet and social networking as tools for spontaneous change. Living in a police state, news, speech, personal freedoms repressed. A government were change is almost non-existant, sow the seeds of dissent. This dissent turns to smoldering hate, and desire for change. And the internet and instant messaging, and almost instantaneous ability to communicate with one another, provides a level of personal freedom that wets the appetitie. Any story, incident real or made up, quickly circulates and motivates those who would make change happen. Welcome to the communication age.

If the culture of the US was objectively seeking the best paths to solving problems, it would not be the country it is.  That which is not objective is irrational, a fantasy.  I learned a long time ago that logic will not change an opinion come to via illogical means.  You are correct.  But sadly, people will have to learn reality via some other vehicle that rational deduction and, even more sadly, the way that people learn that there conceptual world doesn't line up with the real world can cause great destruction and suffering.  The longer the fantasy continues, the greater potential there is for destruction.  You only have to look at the recent financial crisis.  The lies went on a really long time; many people shared the same fantasy; the resulting crash was huge.  I thought the misery and hardship and pain would cause people to see truth, but also sadly, people will cling to their fantasies unless they are truly forced to let go of them.  I don't want to see that much pain.

"Edward Glaeser asserted that freedom is the “moral heart” of economics. His clear account helps explain how many economists think and feel.
...
At least some economists (and I count most of my friends among them) disagree."

Many against some? It certainly look like that from the outside. It least it did for me. Now, being on the inside - it seems like a vast majority of economists would disagree with Glaeser.

Still – a majority would, in their research, (implicitly) argue like they where Glaeserians (including me). Why? Well I guess it’s for the same reason that you want to assume perfect competition (even if you know it’s nonsense), markets in equilibrium (only happens by chance once in a lifetime), perfectly rational agents (really????) etc. That is, because it´s a hundred and five times easier (mathematically, conceptually).

The article ignores two major stories, confirmed in mainstream Mexican media in recent months, that contribute to the cynicism of ordinary Mexican citizens towards Calderon's war on the cartels:

1)Strong, direct ties between President Calderon's cabinet and his security advisers with the Sinaloa Cartel. This was long suspected since that cartel was never directly targeted by the national government and every army "victory" seems to result in more territory for El Chapo Guzman. The newspapers Reforma, La Jornada and magazine Processo, have reported direct evidence of the ties since November. Other newspapers(ones not tied to the PAN party) have covered this story as well.

2)The Mexican government's own human rights panel released a report that about a third of the killings in Chihuahua(Juarez)attributed to the drug war are actually social cleansing(search: "Commission Derechos Humanos Mexicanos" and "limpieza social") by police, army, and vigilantes. These are killings of beggars, homeless, mentally ill, hopeless alcoholics or drug addicts, street kids, and prostitutes; not gangsters, narcos or others in the drug trade as the Mexican government would have the US believe.

This is the 21st Century version of early 20th Century alcohol Prohibition. Whether you like it or not, many people like to get high off of drugs, be they alcohol, nicotine, or marijuana. If you make them illegal a black market will develop along with criminals. These laws will also make criminals out of ordinary citizens who just want to relax after work with a puff of marijuana. Legalize drugs and the black market will shrink and so will the violence.

Sahit Muja: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak needs to resign. This is the time for change in Egypt
The U.S government should commit itself to help Egypt leading to a real democracy. President Hosni Mubarak needs to go.

I am deeply disappointed that President Obama has not shown the moral leadership in this Egyptian crisis . Why is it so hard for President Obama and other politicians to recognize that the principles that helped them to get elected are the same principles that should govern their actions and policies?
In situations like what is happening in Egypt it is easy to become cynical about politics.

The reality is that the United States and Israel have relied on the suppression and impoverishment of the Egyptian people in support of their strategic interests.
Whatever are the final results from the current uprising in Egypt will be the justly deserved fruits of these flawed policies.

This is the time for President Obama to live up to the ideals of the hope and change that he preached about in his campaign. This is the time for USA to break its addiction to dictators for short-term gains.
The history of Saudi Arabia, Afghanistan, Iran, Iraq, Argentina, Haiti, Chile, and so many others should provide sufficient guidance that these alliances with corrupt and despotic regimes are never in the best interests of the USA.

President Obama and the media share some of the blame for the continued suffering of the Egyptian people. President Obama and the U.S., should protest the use of U.S -made U.S.-supplied equipment to intimidate peaceful Egyptian demonstrators.

The F-16s making low passes over the cities. The tanks. The tasers used on demonstrators. The USA supplied those weapons for Egypt’s defense and should protest their use to intimidate or harm Egyptians.
We as citizens of this country must accept our own acquiesce with these polices by not learning about and advocating against the abject political and economic conditions that the these people have endured.

The Egyptian people want the same things Americans want: schools, jobs, food for their families, taxes no higher than necessary, a police force that is a friend to their communities rather than an enemy, a say in the political process, and a government that adjusts policy to match their needs. We can support the Egyptians’ efforts and then work with the new government to ensure that security is maintained in the region.
Sahip Muja
President & CEO
Albanian Minerals
New York

I am Egyptian by birth, and American by choice. I had the very great fortune to come to America for a new life. I was given the opportunity to come here, and have been so blessed. I learned the language, have a job that I love, and have met many wonderful American friends during my years here.

I have not forgotten those less fortunate in my homeland. There are widows, orphans, and many, many poor, disadvantaged people who have no one to help them, no support from their government. They lead a perilous existence, struggling day to day.

I am proud to be an American, and don't want to see my country blamed for the mess in Egypt. Mubarek and his cronies ran the country into the ground, and sadly, the citizens stood by and let it happen. Things worsened recently, yes, but this came to pass over 30 years. It's time for Egyptians to come together, and make their country safe, whole, and prosperous once again.

Your brother in America,

Nagy Hafez

Let me give my 2 cents on this...

We've been living here for the past 3 years. It was calm, a beautiful city, safe in the meaning that there were not that many robberies. For the past year, we are afraid of leaving our houses, we go as fast as we can from and to work and at the most we try to go to a theater. No, there is no tourism or even the will for it.

Another reader pointed out that what caused this was the increased security on borders against drug dealers. However what nobody thought is that if money doesn't come from drugs it would need to come from something else, in this case, robbery.

Also, another problem, HUGE problem is the police. We were stopped by cops about 5 times since we are here. EVERY TIME they asked for a bribe, varying from US$10 to 40. Even Federal Police is corrupt.

In other words: you're robbed by criminals and robbed by the police. How nice is that?

Considering that Calderon's efforts to improve the Police are stuck, I don't see this changing so soon, and yes, we want to get the heck out of here as soon as possible.

It is astounding that we have to debate and delay over sending hundreds of millions to a democratic country with a President devoted to doing the right thing and fighting all illegitimate armed groups in his country(Mexico-Calderon), while at the same time, we fork over billions without question or comment to a country who maintains close ties with our militant enemies, likely gives them much of that money, and has a President widely known to be outrageously corrupt(Pakistan-Zardari). We need a drastic foreign policy re-orientation to support the many democratic countries struggling against crime in our own backyard.
I have been in gun stores in Texas. I have never seen hand grenades for sale in any of those stores. Do the Mexican gangs purchase grenades from Texas?

It costs as little as $250 dollars to have anyone murdered in Juarez. Some hitmen get paid $400 dollars a week which in Mexico is a lot of money.

The problem for Mexico now has to solve is of homicide in a very large scale not a narcotics contraband problem, that has been now superseded. There are presently numerous serial killers for hire on the loose and if this is not contained the next stage will be extortion of the general population by these killers, already we are seeing this in the border cities, from Tijuana to Juarez to Reynosa: doctors are being shaken down and tortured and murdered because they don’t pay protection, many have closed their clinics and fled to the US side, kindergardens and schools are now also being extorted, a kindergarden was set on fire last December in Juarez, gangsters have now started to appear in schools all the way to Mexico City demanding regular payments or else. Gangsters now demand money from small businesses and street vendors all over Mexico. We live in fear seeing how quickly this is spreading. We are being threatened on our home or business phones by gangsters demanding money pretending they have kidnapped a relative or informing us it is better to pay now instead of being kidnapped/tortured/murdered. Thousands of illegal migrants from Central America (I believe 3,000 is the latest number) have disappeared in the last two years after crossing the border, may are feared dead, like the 45 that were found executed last year. Mass grave discoveries are a common occurrence today as are decapitated, mutilated, tortured cadavers, some hung from bridges in Cuernavaca, Acapulco, Monterrey. Many thousands of unsolved murders. Many unreported kidnappings, disappearances, extortions.

These bandidos roam around in caravans of SUV’s, in groups of twenty to fifty, all armed with submachine guns, mostly AR-15’s and Ak-47’s and some grenades and rocket propelled grenades. These weapons are mostly bought legally in Texas and Arizona and smuggled into Mexico. They have lots of cash, military training (lots of military deserters), unlimited cellphones, radios, police and military uniforms. Some are known to US Army trainers, for they were part of the Special Forces (GAFES) contingent trained by them.

Please help us, don’t let any more weapons cross the border, we implore you, these weapons might be for sport in the US but they are used for barbarous crimes in Mexico. I can’t believe Hillary Clinton said last week in Guanajuato that the conflict was going according to expectations and that there were no alternatives but the disaster that is going on now. During her quick visit students there marched in protest of the weapons trade from the US asking it to stop but that did not get reported, not even by the NY Times, check the Mexican media reports from that day.

The three pillars of the New Crime Syndicate of Mexico: Money, Weapons, Drugs.

Money: $30 billion dollars a year, yes, billion with a b, get “laundered” through Mexico from the US. Interdict and confiscate this fortune and you will go far in killing this monster.

Weapons: Estimated at 95,000 assault weapons and pistols exported from the US to Mexico every year, especially since 2004 when the Assault Weapons Ban was repealed by President Bush.

Narcotics: At this point the drugs are the least of the problems Mexico has. Perhaps Mexico should just legalize them and let the Border Patrol deal with the problem, since trying to stop the traffic through the country has caused such destruction and mayhem.

By the way, the Merida Initiative has not worked. Things have only gotten worse, much worse since it came on the table. Try something different, soon.
